Tungstated zirconia supported Ni catalysts with different Ni contents (3 to 20 of % w/w) were synthesized at mild conditions in a stirred pressure reactor. We reported multi-objective optimization (MOO) of tungstated zirconia preparation in terms of Brønsted acid site density and surface area for the first time in the open literature. Optimization of nickel content was also performed in terms of HDO activity and selectivity. Obtained MOO results showed that optimum nickel content was 15% in terms of selectivity and activity. Predicted response results were in good agreement with the experimental response results. The catalytic performance of the catalyst samples was tested on the HDO reaction of guaiacol. Additionally, an HDO mechanism for Ni-doped WOxZrO2 catalyzed guaiacol conversion was proposed. High activity and selectivity rates were achieved during the experiments and cyclohexane was obtained as a main product in the presence of more than 10% of Ni-doped tungstated zirconia catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Response surface methodology Environmental chemistry Tungstated zirconia Catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Environmental and political studies have been conducted for many years to reduce dependency on fossil-based fuel and energy. Biofuels are renewable liquid fuels made from biological crude materials and they are potential substitutes for conventional fuels. The transformation of lignocellulosic biomass is an efficient option for the production of improved biofuels. Bio-oil is an important product that can be obtained using thermal conversion methods such as pyrolysis and liquefaction of biomass. Pyrolysis of bio-oil forms a complex mixture that contains highly oxygenated organic compounds, including phenolic derivatives, carboxylic acids, furans, aldehydes, ketones and esters. It also contains major quantity of water and lignin oligomers [1]. Bio-oil has disadvantages such as high viscosity, high water content, ash content, low thermal value and low energy density because of the oxygenated groups [2,3]. These disadvantages limit the use of bio-oil as a direct fuel. Recent studies have focused on the reduction of the oxygen content of the bio-oil using different methods. There are many methods to upgrade bio-oil, such as emulsification, catalytic esterification, steam reforming, catalytic cracking, catalytic hydrogenation [4]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a quite important method to remove the oxygenated compounds from bio-oil. HDO experiments are conducted at relatively high temperatures (200-400°C) in the presence of a catalyst and under hydrogen atmosphere [5]. During the hydrodeoxygenation process; deoxygenation, hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, decarboxylation, hydrocracking and dehydration reactions occur [6,7]. In the HDO process, catalysts enhance hydrogenation and deoxygenation reactions, which indicates that the reactions occur on the active metallic sites, with acidic sites [8]. Therefore, HDO method is more advantageous and comprehensive than other methods. The catalyst play a major role in HDO process. Besides metals [9–11] metal sulfides [12,13], oxides [14], phosphides [15], nitrides [7,16], carbides [17,18] and their composites with different support materials are frequently used in the search of an ideal catalyst for HDO process. Metal sulfides have been used for a long time to catalyze hydrodesulfurization and hydrodenitrogenation processes in oil refineries. Although metal sulfides have high HDO activities, they are not preferred since they cause a significant decrease in liquid yield and consume a high amount of hydrogen [19]. Due to their low stability, metal sulfides transform into oxide forms and release sulfur-containing gases in oxygenated environments, limiting the use of metal sulfides. Although metal phosphides are effective alternatives to metal sulfides, the rate of coke formation on the surface of metal-phosphide catalyst is higher. For this reason, metal phosphide catalysts can not maintain their effectiveness for a long time; hence they are deactivated [20,21]. Metal carbides are sensitive to water [22,23], and metal nitrides tend to undergo partial oxidation because of an interaction with air [16]. For these reasons, metal carbides and metal nitrides have low stability. The HDO catalysts widely used recently, are a combination of an acidic support materials and metals that act as active sites [24]. In this two-component system, while the metallic region catalyzes the hydrogenation reaction by activating molecular hydrogen, the acidic support material catalyzes dehydration, hydrogenation, isomerization, cracking reactions and provides substrate adsorption [25,26]. Zirconia-based solid catalysts have drawn significant attention recently due to their high stability in water medium [27] and acidic properties that can enhance the catalytic activity and promote cracking, isomerization, hydration and dehydration reactions [28]. Despite the valuable features, zirconia mostly consists of Lewis type acidic regions. Lewis acid sites are responsible for coke formation on the catalyst; therefore, these regions decrease the catalytic activity [29]. Tungsten addition is a crucial step to adjust the ratio of Brønsted acid sites to Lewis acid sites. Tungstated zirconia allows the formation of Brønsted acid sites, suppress coke formation and increase the dispersion of hydrogen activator metal on the support material [30]. Strong interactions between zirconia and tungsten decrease the surface diffusion, to an increase in the surface area and suppress the sintering of active metals [31,32]. Many reaction parameters such as tungsten ratio, reaction time and calcination temperature, significantly affect the end properties of WOx-ZrO2 support catalyst. Total acidity of WOx-ZrO2 is increased with increasing tungsten ratio. However, high acidity leads to coke formation and high tungsten content has a critical effect on the crystal structure of zirconia [33]. Calcination temperature, as well as reaction time, directly influence the surface area of the support material [34–36]. Brønsted acid sites are desired to obtain high surface area and acidity. Response surface methodology (RSM) is an important tool to design experiments with the aim of evaluating the effects of process parameters on the various responses and optimizing the process [37,38]. RSM allows us to save time and material by reducing the number of experiments and provides sufficient information for statistically acceptable results as well [39]. In this study, RSM was used to investigate the individual and interaction effects of tungsten ratio, reaction time and calcination temperature coefficient variation on the surface area and Brønsted acid site density [(B/B+L) x 100] of the support material. Instead of noble metals such as Pd, Pt, Ru etc. nickel is used as a moleculer hydrogen activating catalyst due to the extraordinary hydrogenation capability [40] and low cost, in comparison with that of noble metal catalysts. The density of the nickel on the support material surface is another critical parameter and has a direct impact on the hydrodeoxygenation performance of total catalyst. Different nickel concentrations (3-20%) were investigated and optimal ratio of the nickel was stated using MOO results. In conclusion, we report for the first time the MOO of tungstated zirconia preparation in terms of Brønsted acid site density and surface area. Prepared WOx-ZrO2 was used as a support material for nickel metal in different concentrations. Optimization of nickel content was also performed in terms of HDO activity and selectivity. Catalytic performance of the catalyst was tested on the HDO reaction of guaiacol, which is frequently used as a model compound of bio-oil [24,25]. Guaiacol consists of two different oxygenated functions (phenolic and methoxy groups); therefore, they are challenging molecules to be completely deoxygenated [25]. The prepared catalyst was fully characterized via various techniques. Additionally, a HDO mechanism for Ni doped WOxZrO2 catalyzed guaiacol conversion was proposed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials For the synthesis of tungstated zirconia, zirconium (IV) oxide chloride octahydrate and ammonium metatungstate hydrate were used as zirconia and tungsten precursor, respectively. Ammonnia was used to transform the zirconium (IV) oxide chloride to zirconium hydroxide. Nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate was used to immobilize metallic nickel particles onto the surface of the support material. In HDO experiments, guaiacol and isooctane were used as a reactant and solvent, respectively. All chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without any further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of WOx-ZrO2 as Support Material 2.2.1 Experimental design and data set Designing a set of experiments is considered the first stage of the RSM. The experimental design is the most essential part that yields adequate and reliable measurements of the response of interest. Occasionally, an experiment can be composed of more than one response. Here, the experiment is called multi-response experiment, which requires careful consideration due to multiple response nature of the experimental data. To reach optimal synthesis conditions of tungstated zirconia support material, reaction time (X 1 ), W content (X 2 ) and calcination temperature (X 3 ) were chosen as three factors (k=3). These are the main reaction conditions that likely to affect two responses (r=2), which are surface area (Y 1 ) and Brønsted acid site density (Y 2 ). Here, k is the number of factors and r is the number of responses. The current experiment determines the effects of X 1, X 2, X 3 on the Y1, Y2 . Simultaneous maximization of Y1 and Y2 would be desirable. The choice of the design affects the functional relationship between the responses and factors. Generally, second-order designs are preferred to use in experimental studies. Central Composite Design (CCD) is one of the second order designs which provides sufficient information about the study with a small number of experiments. Thus, in this study, the experiments were conducted in CCD. The CCD consisted of 17 experiments divided into three blocks: (i) factorial points 2 k (23=8 experiments) corresponding to three factors at two levels, low (-1) and high (+1), (ii) axial points 2k (2 × 3=6 experiments) located at the center and both extreme levels, low (-α) and high (+α), and (iii) central points (3 experiments). Alpha is defined as a distance from the center point, which can be either inside the range or outside, with the maximum value of 2 k/4 . Hereby the value of alpha was set at 1.682. Actual levels of factors were chosen according to the previous experiments for five-level-three-factor CCD in this study. The actual and coded values of each factor are presented in Table 1 . The experimental points, in actual (coded) values, and the response values are presented in Table 2 . Experiments were carried out in random order to obtain a good estimation of errors. 2.2.2 General procedure for the synthesis of tungstated zirconia Zirconium oxyhydroxide was prepared by the hydrolysis of 10 g zirconium oxychloride aqueous solution with the addition of ammonia solution up to pH of 10.5. The resulting slurry was refluxed for 2h. The precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water to remove chloride ions and AgNO3 solution was used to be sure that there were no chloride ions remaining. The obtained zirconium oxyhydroxide was dried at 100 °C for 12 h. Tungstated zirconia was prepared via wet impregnation method. Zirconium oxyhydroxide was mixed with different amounts of aqueous ammonium metatungstate solution. The final solution was refluxed within the specified time periods. The obtained WOxZrO2 catalysts were dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcinated in air at different temperatures with 10 °C/min of heating rate for 6h. 2.3 Preparation of catalyst To obtain HDO catalyst, pre-synthesized WOxZrO2 was mixed with a different amount of nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate according to the desired nickel content. Then, 25 mL of ethanol and 25 mL of distilled water were added to the mixture. The prepared solution was sonicated for 2 h and stirred for 10 h at room temperature. At the end of the time, slurry was evaporated and the remaining solid phase was dried and calcinated at 500 °C with 3 °C/min of heating rate for 5 h. After calcination, the catalyst was activated at 600 °C under H2 atmosphere according to the TPR results. 2.4 Characterization procedure Crystalline structures were characterized by Inel Equinox 1000 X-ray diffractometer using CoKα radiation. To investigate surface morphology, scanning electron microscope (SEM-EDAX) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) were used. Images were taken using ZEISS EVO 40 (500 V - 30 kV) and FEI Tecnai G2 (200 kV) instruments, respectively. Particle size distribution analyses were conducted via laser particle size analyser Malvern Hydro 2000 MU. Pore size distribution was analysed using the Quantachrome NOVA 2200 series instrument. Nitrogen gas having a purity of 99.99 % was used as the adsorbed gas. XPS spectra were recorded with PHI-5000 Versaprobe instrument using an Al monochromatic X-ray anode. Obtained peaks were plotted using Gaussian curves. To determine the Brønsted acid site density, FT-IR analyses were conducted for pyridine-adsorbed catalyst according to Ginjupalli et al. [36]. According to the procedure, pyridine was adsorbed on the activated catalysts at 200°C until saturation. Before adsorption, all catalysts were activated under nitrogen flow at 350°C for an hour to remove moisture. IR spectra were recorded at room temperature by using an IR spectrometer with KBr disc. Collected results were processed to obtain B/B+L ratio as a percentage. The IR bands appeared around 1540–1548 cm−1 and 1445–1460 cm−1 are characteristic bands of Brønsted (B) and Lewis (L) acid sites, respectively. Additionally, the bands referred to the sum of both Brønsted and Lewis (B + L) acid sites appeared around 1490–1500 cm−1 [34]. The B/B+L ratio was calculated based on the peak areas of these bands [27] Temperature-programmed ammonia desorption (NH3-TPD), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and single-point BET analyses were conducted via Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720 instrument. The acidic properties of the catalysts were investigated by using NH3-TPD analyses. For each analysis, 30 mg of catalyst samples were placed into a U-shaped quartz tube and positioned in the furnace and pre-treated under helium flow (20 ml.min−1) at 220°C for 30 min and cooled to 100 °C. Ammonia was adsorbed at 100 °C for 30 min with flow of 5 % (v/v) NH3/He carrier gas. Thereafter, the system was purged by using helium gas (25 ml.min−1) to remove any NHx molecule remaining. Finally, ammonia desorption was monitored using TCD detector by heating the catalysts from 100 to 610 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under helium flow (25 ml.min−1). Reduction profiles of the catalysts were obtained by using temperature-programmed reduction analyses. For each analysis, 50 mg of fresh catalyst samples were taken into a U-shaped quartz tube and pre-treated with helium flow (20 ml.min−1) at 220 °C and cooled to 35 °C. 5 % (v/v) H2/Ar gas mixture was employed at 35 °C. Then, the temperature was raised to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of 5% (v/v) H2/Ar gas and reduction profiles were simultaneously monitored by a TCD detector. In order to remove the water that produced during the heating process, a cold trap was used. The surface areas of prepared catalysts were determined by using single-point BET method. For each analysis, 300 mg of catalyst samples were placed into a U-shaped borosilicate tube. N2/He gas mixture was employed with the flow of 25 ml.min−1. Nitrogen adsorption was conducted at boiling point of liquid nitrogen (-196 °C) and monitored by a TCD detector. Each sample was tested in triplicate. The metal dispersion percentages were investigated by conducting CO Pulse Chemisorption using Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720 instrument. Quartz U-tube was loaded with 100 mg of sample. Prior to pulse CO chemisorption, catalysts were reduced at 605 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min in 5% (v/v) H2/Ar gas mixture with a flow rate of 50 ml/min for two hours. Then, the sample was cooled down to room temperature with helium flow (20 mLmin−1) to remove the reducing gas. Pulse chemisorption was carried out at room temperature by pulsing 1 ml 10% CO/He mixture until the sample was saturated. Metallic surface area data were calculated from the dispersion results that obtained from the instrument. Carbon can be found in three different phases at the end of the HDO reaction; solid (coke), gas and liquid. The amount of carbon in the gas phase was calculated using microGC analysis results, the amount of carbon in solid phase was calculated from the coke results. The initial amount of carbon was calculated from the amount of guaiacol added before the HDO reaction. The amount of carbon in the liquid phase was also obtained by subtracting the amount of carbon obtained from solid and gas phases from the initial carbon amount. Liquid product analyses were performed to understand the HDO pathway and catalytic performances of catalysts. GC-MS analyses of liquid samples were performed using Agilent Technologies 6890N Network GC System gas chromatography and Agilent Technologies 5975B VL MSD mass spectrometer, containing HP-5MS 5% phenyl methyl siloxane (30.0 m x 250 µm x 0.25 µm) capillary column. 1 µL of the sample was injected in the splitless mode. The oven temperature was kept at 40°C for 2 min and then increased to 300°C with a heating rate of 20°C/min and maintaned at this temperature constant for 2 min. The total analysis time was determined as 17 min. High purity helium was used as a carrier gas with a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min. Quantitative analyses of the liquid products were performed by Agilent Technologies 6890N Network GC System gas chromatography with HP-5 5% phenyl methyl siloxane (30.0 m x 250 µm x 0.25 µm) capillary column. According to the procedure, 1 µL of the sample was injected in the splitless mode. The inlet temperature was set at 190°C and the detector temperature 250°C. The total gas flow was 13.5 ml/min. The oven temperature was kept at 50°C for 2 min and then increased to 240°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min and maintaned at this temperature constant for 2 min. Selectivity analyses were performed on GC-MS analysis. In the selectivity analysis, calculations were made directly from the peak areas without using an internal standard. Activity performances of the catalysts were analyzed by GC-MS and calculations were made according to the internal standard method by adding 50 µL of dodecan to each sample. Gaseous product analyses were performed with SRA Instruments T-3000 model micro gas chromatography (μGC) which has TCD detector and two modules consist of MS5A and PPU columns. 2.5 Catalytic activity tests – HDO experiments HDO experiments were carried out in 300 mL of stirred pressure reactor (Parr, model 4571) under 20 bar hydrogen pressure at 250°C for 3 h. Isooctane was used as a solvent. A mixture of 5 mL of guaiacol, 100 ml of isooctane and activated catalyst was placed into the reactor. For the activation of catalysts, the experiments were conducted in a quartz tube under 40 cm3/min of H2 flow, located in temperature-controlled furnace heated from room temperature to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. After activation of the catalyst, all components were put in the reactor and purged with nitrogen to remove air, then autoclave was filled with hydrogen. At the end of the reaction time, gaseous products were taken into a tedlar bag for analysis. The solid product was separated from the liquid via vacuum filtration and dried and calcinated at 632°C for 6 h to remove coke on the catalyst surface. After calcination, oxidized catalyst was activated under H2 flow according to the procedure given above. The recycled catalyst was also used again to determine the reusability performance. Activity, selectivity and reusability performances of catalysts were determined as indicated in Eqs. (1)–(3). (1) A c t i v i t y ( % ) = [ G u a i a c o l ] i n i t i a l − [ G u a i a c o l ] r e m a i n i n g [ G u a i a c o l ] i n i t i a l x 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = [ o x y g e n − f r e e c o m p o u n d s ] o b t a i n e d [ o x y g e n a t e d c o m p o u n d s ] o b t a i n e d x 100 (3) R e u s e a b i l i t y ( % ) = c o n v e r s i o n r a t e o f t h i r d r u n ( % ) A c o n v e r s i o n r a t e o f f i r s t r u n ( % ) x 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Statistical modeling One of the main aims in the experiments is to build an appropriate model between responses and factors for the collected data from the design. Modeling is the second stage of the RSM. In multi-response experiments, simultaneous consideration of multiple responses is necessary for building an appropriate model for the responses. Generally, multivariate regression analysis is applied for multi-response modeling. If responses are uncorrelated and have the same experimental design, classical regression analysis is used as a basic modeling tool to define the functional relationship between the responses and the factors. Based on the CCD, the relationship between the response and coded valued factors, given in Table 2, was evaluated by the second-order polynomial regression model as follows: (4) Y = β 0 + ∑ i = 1 k β i X I ˙ + ∑ i = 1 k β i i X i 2 + ∑ i = 1 k − 1 ∑ j = 2 k β i j X i X j + ε Where X1,X2,…,Xk are the factors, which influence the response Y, β0 is the intercept, βi ’s are the linear order coefficients, βii ’s are the quadratic coefficients of the i th factor and βij ’s are the linear model coefficients for the interaction between the factors i and j (i, j = 1,2,…,k, i < j). Here, all the β0, βi, βii and βij are called model parameters [37]. In the beginning of analysis in modeling stage, the correlation between the surface area (Y 1) and Brønsted acid site density (Y 2) should be checked. For this purpose, nonparametric correlation coefficient is calculated since the response values are not normally distributed. Spearman rho coefficient was obtained as -0.231, which was not statistically significant at 5% level of significance (p-value> 0.05). Therefore, each response can be modeled individually. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was carried out to check the adequacy of the predicted response models for surface area (Y 1) and Brønsted acid site density (Y 2), conducted at 5% level of significance. The calculations were done in SPSS program by using regression analysis toolbox. Results of ANOVA with model parameter estimates are given in Table 3 and Table 4 for the responses surface area (Y 1) and Brønsted acid site density (Y 2), respectively. It can be easily seen from Table 3 that the predicted model with linear, quadratic and interaction terms for surface area (Y 1) is not significant since the p-value is not less than 5% level of significance (p-value=0.231). From Table 3, only the model term X 3 is significant for Y 1. Therefore, the predicted model is composed of only the factor calcination temperature (X 3 ) with statistically significant (p-value=0.003<0.05). According to the statistics, given in Table 3, the predicted response model for the first response can be written as follows: (5) Y 1 ^ = 52.76 − 19.8 X 3 The determination coefficient (R2 ) is equal to 0.458, which indicates that 45.8% of the first response variability in the experimental data could be explained by the predicted model given in Eq. 5. The lack of fit, which is the weighted sum of squared deviations between the mean response at each factor level and the corresponding fitted value, is not significant for the first response (lack of fit p-value=0.087 > 0.05 is not significant) which indicates that the predicted model, given in Eq. 5, fits to all data. It is clear from Table 4 that the predicted model with linear, quadratic and interaction terms for Brønsted acid site density (Y2 ) is significant since the p-value is less than 0.05 (p-value=0.018). The model terms, X 1 , X 3 , X 2 2 and X 1 X 3 are significant for Y 2. In this modeling, it is preferred to keep the individual term of W content (X 2) in the model since it is required to support the model hierarchy. By using the statistics given in Table 4, the predicted response model for Brønsted acid site density (Y 2) becomes (6) Y 2 ^ = 69.27 + 12.12 X 1 + 6.72 X 2 + 9.32 X 3 − 10.15 X 2 2 − 15.63 X 1 X 3 The determination coefficient (R2 ) is equal to 0.852, which indicates that 85.2% of the second response variability in the experimental data was explained by the predicted model given in Eq. (6). From Table 4, the lack of fit is significant for the second response (p-value=0.017<0.05). This indicates that the predicted model, given in Eq. (6), cannot fit all the data. Therefore, all the data, given in Table 2, were checked individually. It was seen that the 10th observation had large residuals. Here, it should be proper to remove this observation from the data. However, it cannot be removed since each observation is an important part of the CCD. As consequence, the predicted response models based on the coded factor values, given in Eqs. (5)-(6), were accepted as predicted response models that fit the data well. Response surface plots were used to visualize the interactions of factors on the responses. The three-dimensional (3-D) plots were produced by keeping one of the three factors constant at their center point, while the other two variables were varied along the x- and y-axis, with the response was assigned to the other axis. These figures can be seen in Appendix (Fig. S1-3). Fig. 1 shows the relationship between the experimental (observed) and predicted values of responses to present the accuracy of the models for surface area (Y 1) and Brønsted acid site density (Y 2), respectively. Predicted results were determined according to Eq. (5) for surface area and Eq. (6) for Brønsted acid site density. Fig. 1 was plotted experimental results against predicted results for each of the specific reaction conditions. The plotted points clustering around the diagonal line presents quite acceptable agreement between the predicted and experimental values in Fig. 1. 3.2 Optimization of synthesis parameters in multi-objective perspective The third stage of the RSM is optimization, which is about determining the optimal settings of the experimental factors that produce the maximum (or minimum) value of the response. The optimal values of factors are obtained using either derivative-based or derivative free optimization algorithms. In multi-response experiments, the multi-response problem is considered a MOO problem. Here, it should be better to achieve the optimization by using MOO tools. After obtaining predicted response models, given in Eq. 5-6, the optimization stage was dealt in a multi-objective perspective since the multi-response optimization problem can be viewed as a MOO. The MOO problem is formulated as (7) max x ψ 1 = Y 1 ^ ( X ) max x ψ 2 = Y 2 ^ ( X ) X ϵ S where S is a search space. In this study, Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm-II (NSGA-II), a well-known population based MOO algorithm, was used as a MOO tool [41]. By using the NSGA-II, infinite number of alternative solutions, called the Pareto solution set, were generated. The NSGA-II was applied with the tuning parameters as n p o p = 120 , n g e n = 100 , Pr c r o s s = 0.90 , Pr m u t = 0.01 , tournament selection, SBX crossover and polynomial mutation, which are defined by using expert knowledge [42]. The obtained Pareto solution set is presented in Fig. 2 . When the Fig. 2 is examined, it is expected that 120 Pareto solutions should be seen since tuning parameters of npop is chosen equal to 120. However, from Fig. 2, it seems that there are five non-dominated solutions in the Pareto set. When the results were examined in detail, it was seen that some of the 120 non-dominated solutions had the same objective function values which were reduced to five different non-dominated solutions. The experimental conditions, defined as factor values, for five non-dominated solutions are presented with real and coded values in Table 5 . Additionally, predicted response values for surface area (Y 1) and Brønsted acid site density (Y 2) are also given in Table 5. Experimental studies conducted using factor levels were given in Table 5 and experimental response values were collected. Predicted and experimental response values were given in Table 6 . To measure the similarity between the predicted and the experimental response values, given in Table 6, were figured out in Fig. 3 for both surface area (Y1 ) and Brønsted acid site density (Y2 ). FT-IR spectra of pyridine-adsorbed P1-5 samples were given in Fig S4. It can be easily seen from Fig. 3 that the most preferred solution is the fourth Pareto solution, numbered P4, since the predicted and the observed response values are closer for Y 1 and Y 2, respectively. Thus, the solution P4 is considered a compromise solution. The optimal conditions for simultaneously maximization of surface area (Y 1) and Brønsted acid site density (Y 2) were determined as follows: reaction time, 10h 45m; W content, 18 %; calcination temperature, 632 °C. 3.3 Optimization of Ni content in the support material for HDO of guaiacol By using the optimum conditions for WOxZrO2 support material (reaction time, 10h 45min; W content, 18 %; calcination temperature, 632 °C), it was planned to define the optimum conditions for Ni content. For this purpose, Ni levels were defined as 3, 5, 10 and 20. The experimental data set is given in Table 7 . It can be said from Table 7 that three runs of the experiment were done to get observed replicated response values for the activity and selectivity. Regression analysis was performed on the dataset given in Table 7. The obtained results were presented in Fig. 4 . It can be said from the Fig. 4 that the optimum condition for Ni was 15% in terms of activity and selectivity. The experiment was conducted at this optimal condition (15% Ni content). The obtained three replicated response results are 84, 83, 81% for activity and 82, 82, 81% for selectivity. According to these observed response results, it is possible to say that the predicted and the experimental response values are closer to each other at 15% Ni content. 3.4 Characterization of catalyst The crystal structures of samples were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. XRD patterns of WOxZrO2 and 15Ni-WOxZrO2 samples are depicted in Fig. 5 . The monoclinic phase is thermodynamically stable phase of ZrO2 [43,44]. The addition of tungsten oxide (higher than 10%) leads to a formation of the diffraction peaks belonged to the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 by suppressing the formation of monoclinic ZrO2 phase since W loading helps stabilisation tetragonal zirconia [34] and reduces the surface mobility of zirconia [35]. In contrast, at low WOx content, the characteristic peak of WOx was not observed since it was highly distributed on ZrO2 surface or amorphous phase [35,44,45]. In parallel with the literature, characteristic diffraction peaks of tetragonal (2θ = 34.3°, 40.2°, 43.3°, 58° and 70°) and monoclinic phase of ZrO2 (2θ=27.5°, 32.2°, 35.9°) were observed [43,46]. With the addition of nickel, two new peaks appeared at around 51.3° and 60°, which were attributed to Ni0 and Ni+2 species, respectively [47–50]. XPS analysis was conducted to examine the surface chemical phase of metals. Zr 3d XPS spectra of tungstated zirconia support is given in Fig 6 A. XPS results of WOxZrO2 samples confirm that the two peaks at 182.2 and 184.7 eV correspond to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 electrons of Zr4+, respectively [51]. W 4f and Zr 4p XPS spectra of WOxZrO2 are shown in Fig 6B. The obtained spectra can be deconvoluted into four peaks at 30.68, 32.11, 35.68 and 37.81. The first two peaks are assigned to Zr (4p), and the last two peaks correspond to W+6. [36] After semi-quantitative analysis, it was observed that the structure of tungstate consists of W+6 form. Ni 2p XPS spectra of 15Ni-WOxZrO2 catalyst was shown in Fig. 7 . The obtained spectra can be deconvoluted into seven peaks. Two regions indicate of Ni 2p1/2 and Ni 2p3/2, containing a primary peak and satellite peak caused by electron shakeup [52,53]. Except satellites, presence of Ni+2 and Ni0 species was confirmed with four peaks observed at 852.7 ev (Ni0 2p3/2), 877.5 ev (Ni0 2p1/2), 880.0 ev (Ni2+ 2p1/2) and 854.7 ev (Ni2+ 2p3/2) [40,54]. According to the semi-quantitative analysis, metallic nickel is the dominant species, Ni+2 may either be in the form of NiO or coordinated with the WOxZrO2. Reduction behavior of WOxZrO2 was studied by H2-TPR analysis. TPR profile shows that WOxZrO2 has a multi-step reduction process. These steps were reported as WO3→WO2.9→WO2→ W. Fig. 8 (top-inset) shows three peaks at a temperature range of 95 °C to 420 °C and these peaks were attributed to WO3→WO2.9→WO2 reduction pattern. WO2→W reduction step can also be seen between 750 – 850 °C. The broad peak centered at 900 °C indicates the reduction of WOx species that bonded with ZrO2 strongly [19]. H2-TPR curves of WOxZrO2 and 15Ni-WOxZrO2 catalysts are depicted in Fig 8 (bottom). It can be seen from the figure that 15Ni-WOxZrO2 represents two peaks. The first peak is in the range of 320-410 °C and the second one is relatively narrow and in the range of 410-600 °C. Ni reduction profile was defined by several studies with different temperature ranges [55–57]. The reduction behavior of NiO particles was investigated and two peaks were observed in the temperature range of 350-520 °C. The first peak was reported as the reduction of Ni2+→Ni (350–420 °C) [22,58-61] and it is in correlation with our study. However, the second peak at higher temperature (520 °C) was attributed to the reduction of NiO molecules interacting with support by different strengths [50]. Because of the obtained TPR profile, activation procedure was conducted at 600 °C for nickel-promoted WOxZrO2 catalysts. A temperature-programmed ammonia desorption (NH3-TPD) profiles of WOxZrO2 and 15Ni-WOxZrO2 are depicted in Fig. 9 . Acid sites of catalysts can be identified based on their temperature at which ammonia molecules are desorbed. These acid sites are weak sites (below 200 °C), medium sites (200-350 °C) and strong sites (350-600 °C) [62]. As shown in Fig. 9, nickel-promoted catalyst has a broad peak at a temperature range of 400-550 °C, meaning that catalyst have mainly strong acid sites. Small desorption peaks were also observed at lower temperature range. On the other hand, WOxZrO2 exhibited a broad peak at 325 °C and a small peak at lower temperature, which was also observed in nickel-promoted catalysts, at 170 °C. Therefore, WOxZrO2 has weak, medium and strong acidic sites, whereas 15Ni-WOxZrO2 has mainly strong acidic sites. BET surface areas of synthesized catalysts are listed in Table 8 . Metal loading decreases the surface area of the support because of the pore blockage [50]. This situation was observed in 3 and 5% of nickel content. At 15% nickel loading, it is assumed that formation of multi-layer nickel oxide appeared and increased the surface area [63]. At higher nickel content (20%), an agglomeration was thought to have occurred, which blocked the pores of nickel compound. Thus, led to a decrease in the surface area of 20Ni-WOxZrO2 and 15Ni-WOxZrO2 showed the highest surface area among nickel-promoted catalysts. It can be seen that adding metal to the support decreased the acidic strength. The amount of promoted metal did not make a significant difference in terms of acidic strength of the catalysts. Additionally, acidic strengths of fresh catalysts were decreased after HDO experiments (spent). Coke formation on the catalyst was decreased with increasing metal content. Higher metal content might have caused the further hydrogenation of coke to carbon containing gaseous products. The increase of the carbon containing gaseous products can be explained with this phenomenon. Based on the level of nickel loading, dispersion results of synthesized catalysts varied. It can be seen from the Table 9 that dispersion % results were decreased with the increase in nickel loading [63]. Metallic surface area (m2/g sample) is important in terms of activity of the catalyst since it refers to more metal sites that can activate the hydrogen in the system. From Table 9, 15Ni-WOxZrO2 catalyst has the maximum value of the metallic surface area (m2/g sample) and it decreased from 0.71 to 0.55 m2/g sample when the nickel content is reached 20%. The value of the metallic surface area (m2/g metal) was also decreased with the increased nickel content as expected. TOF values calculated according to the literature. [64] Highest TOF value was obtained for 15Ni-WOxZrO2 catayst as expected. The lowest TOF value, on the other hand, was observed when 3Ni-WOxZrO2 was used. It was observed that TOF values increased with the increased nickel content. However after the Ni addition above 15% it was decreased. Particle size distribution analyses were conducted via Malvern Hydro 2000 MU instrument. As shown in Fig. S5, spectrum of used 15Ni-WOxZrO2 was wider than that of the fresh catalyst. Therefore, average particle size of 15Ni-WOxZrO2 was increased after it was used on HDO experiments, as given in the previous study [65]. Pore volume of 15Ni-WOxZrO2 did not show a difference as seen in Table S1; nonetheless, the average pore diameter shifted from 7.2 nm to 8.1 nm. This increase might be result from metal redispersion caused by various mechanisms when the catalyst was subjected to HDO experiment, as previously reported by Bartholomew and Farrauto [66]. Fig. 10 A-B show SEM and TEM images of WOxZrO2 samples. As seen from Fig. 10B, WOx-ZrO2 particles were synthesized in a size of about 20 nm. However, agglomerated particles of WOx-ZrO2 were seen according to Fig. 10. Since the particles are in nano-sized, larger particles formed by the agglomeration are observed in also SEM images (Fig. 10A). EDAX analysis (Fig. S6) obtained from the SEM image shows that the tungsten content is about 18%. Ni particles were clearly observed in TEM image of the 15Ni-WOxZrO2 (Fig. 10D). Ni particles having higher particle size than the WOx-ZrO2 was formed in a spherical shape. However, the homogeneous distribution of metals on the support material is positively evaluated in terms of catalytic activity. This phenomenon is also evidenced by the SEM images of 15Ni-WOxZrO2 (Fig. 10 C). EDAX result (Fig. S6) confirms that 15 % Ni is successfully immobilized on WOxZrO2 support. Lower levels of carbon atoms are observed in both samples, which might be caused by the contamination from the analysis environment. 3.5 Hydrodeoxygenation results of guaiacol According to the μGC analysis results (Table 10 ) mole percent of hydrogen decreased significantly until the nickel content reached 15%. When the nickel ratio increases from 15 to 20, an increase in the amount of hydrogen was observed. These results are in agreement with the hydrogen consumption capacity results of the catalyst. Hydrogen consumption of the catalysts were calculated based on observed final pressure and μGC results. Hydrogen consumption of the catalysts was increased with increasing nickel content until 15%. As hydrogen plays an important role in the HDO process, a correlation was observed between the hydrogen consumption and the activity of the catalyst, as expected. Since the use of hydrogen in the HDO process is started by the activation of hydrogen on the active metal, there should be a correlation between the metallic surface area and the hydrogen consumption. This correlation is clearly seen in Fig. 11 . The curve in Fig. 11 is also similar to the activity and selectivity curves obtained in Fig. 4. It is obviously seen from Table 10, more oxygen atoms were eliminated as carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide with increasing nickel content. Although this will lead to carbon loss, carbon balance above 90% was obtained for all catalysts. The carbon balance calculated in the liquid phase was 92.38% for 15Ni-WOxZrO2 (Table S2). Only 9% conversion (mostly to various dioxygenated compounds) was obtained in the presence of bare WOx-ZrO2. According to Fig. 12 , an increase in nickel loading onto WOxZrO2 support leads to a significant increase in the amount of oxygen free compounds. The higher Ni amounts increase the activity/selectivity and also accelerate the removal of oxygen until 15%. In the presence of 15Ni/WOx-ZrO2 catalyst, 84% activity and 82% selectivity rates were achieved. These are the highest rates compared to activity and selectivity rates of other catalyst (Table 7) and quite in accordance with predicted results (Fig. 4). The reusability performances of all catalysts were given in Table S3. Reusability rates of all catalysts except 15Ni/WOx-ZrO2 were obtained between 80.9 and 89.7%. However, the rate for 15Ni/WOx-ZrO2, which is the optimum catalyst, was 96.0 %. Higher reusability rates for all catalysts might be related to the low coke formation because high Brønsted acid site density of support material prevents coke formation. In order to strengthen this claim additional catalyst was prepared with the highest Lewis acid site density support material according to the conditions given in Table 2 No1. Obtained results showed that all three responses (activity, selectivity and reusability) rates were drastically decreased when the Lewis acid sites were dominant (57% of activity, 47% of selectivity, 70% of reusability). Additionally, the amount of coke formed on the catalyst after HDO reaction was also increased to 3.4%. Another reason for the increase in the amount of oxygen free compounds might be related to the increased surface area especially in the presence of 15Ni-WOxZrO2 catalyst as seen in Table 8 [67]. This increase was related to the increase of metallic surface area which is mentioned above. A sharp decrease in the surface area of the 20Ni-WOxZrO2 may cause decrease in the amount of oxygen free compounds with also activity and selectivity percentages. 1,2-dimethoxybenzene is the transalkylated product of guaiacol and formed because of methoxylation reaction (Fig. 13 ). These alkyl transfer reactions are catalyzed by the acid sites of the support material and helped to preserve the carbon in the liquid products. As expected in the presence of support alone, 1-2 dimethoxybenzene was mainly observed in the liquid phase [68–70]. Cyclopentane is a saturated five-membered cyclic hydrocarbon. Cyclopentane and its derivatives as a by-product of HDO are rarely observed in literature [71,72]. Cyclopentanone formation mechanism from guaiacol hydrodeoxygenation was presented by Gao et al. [72]. According to their DFT studies, the possible steps for cyclopentanone formation in the reaction system include partial hydrogenation of the aromatic ring; isomerization; keto−enol tautomerism; α-diketones decarbonylation and ringclosing, respectively. In our study cyclopentane is obtained instead of cyclopentanone because of the possible hydrogenation reaction of cyclopentanone. 1,1-bicyclohexyl was also monitored in liquid phase. According to the Gutiérrez-Rubio et al. [1] phenol can be alkylated with cyclohexene, formed as intermediate in the demethylation route, yielding to biscyclohexylphenol which, after subsequent hydrogenation and dehydration reactions, leads to formation of 1,1-bicyclohexyl as the final product. As we mentioned above alkylation reactions are strongly affected by the acidity of catalyst. It is reasonable that the formation of 1,1-bicyclohexyl is expected due to the acidic nature of the tungstated zirconia. 6-Metoxy-5-hexen-1-ol was monitored as HDO by-product. Although nickel is 3d transition metals, it is found that nickel as an active metal leads to a ring opening for multiple hydrogenolysis of C-C bonds. It was thought that 2-methoxy-cyclohexane-1-one can further react strong interaction with the acidic surface of Ni catalyst which weakens the C–C bond enough to cleave, thus forming ring-opening products [73,74]. Besides these by-products, cyclohexane and benzene were obtained as the main products. Benzene was replaced by cyclohexane with an increasing amount of nickel. Also, increasing hydrogen consumption with increasing Ni content could be explained with the benzene to cyclohexane conversion. Two main products (cyclohexane and cyclopentane) obtained in the presence of 15Ni-WOxZrO2 catalyst were hydrogenated aromatic compounds in parallel with higher hydrogen consumption. It was observed that, catalysts containing small amounts of nickel, promoted benzene formation 1,2 dimethoxybenzene and/or phenol. However, as the nickel content increases, both the reaction route and the main product type vary. Due to the hydrogenation ability of nickel, hydrogenation reactions over the 2-methoxy-cyclohexane-1-one pathway attract attention. 4 Conclusion Tungstated zirconia support material was successfully synthesized via response surface methodology with high surface area and Brønsted acid site density by means of the optimization of reaction parameters such as reaction time (2-12 h), W content (≈ 3-37 %) and calcination temperature (630-970 °C). Nickel, due to the excellent hydrogenation ability and low cost, was immobilized onto the optimal tungstated zirconia with different amounts. The combination of all these steps resulted in a quite good hydrodeoxygenation catalyst. This HDO catalyst has been perfected with optimization of nickel content via regression analysis. Firstly, we performed the HDO experiments in the presence of different nickel amount such as 3, 5, 10 and 20 %. However, %15 appeared as the best nickel content according to the analysis results in terms of activity and selectivity of the catalyst. A perfect match was observed between experimental and predicted results of %15 Ni doped catalyst. Optimal HDO catalyst was characterized in detail. 15Ni/WOx-ZrO2 showed the maximum surface area and metallic surface area compared to catalysts containing different amount of nickel. Benzene and cyclohexane, which are the target compounds of the HDO process of guaiacol, were obtained as main HDO products. Benzene was replaced by cyclohexane when the amount of nickel was increased above %10 and reaction path was also changed to hydrogenation route instead of acid catalyzed routes. Hydrogen consumption was increased until Ni content reached 15% in accordance with activity and metallic surface area results. Transalkylation reactions occured thanks to the acidic nature of catalyst and prevented the carbon loss. At least 90% carbon balance was observed for all catalyzed experiments. Additionally, Lewis acid site dominant catalyst was also tested for comparison. Obtained results showed that the type of acid site played a major role in terms of activity, selectivity and reusability in HDO reactions. The estimated reaction mechanism and pathways were also given. RSM allowed to evaluate wide reaction conditions with less number of experiments. In conclusion, a broad range of reaction conditions were applied and the optimal catalyst formulation for nickel immobilized tungstated zirconia catalysts was stated. coredata.dc:description: Tungstated zirconia supported Ni catalysts with different Ni contents (3 to 20 of % w/w) were synthesized at mild conditions in a stirred pressure reactor. We reported multi-objective optimization (MOO) of tungstated zirconia preparation in terms of Brønsted acid site density and surface area for the first time in the open literature. Optimization of nickel content was also performed in terms of HDO activity and selectivity. Obtained MOO results showed that optimum nickel content was 15% in terms of selectivity and activity. Predicted response results were in good agreement with the experimental response results. The catalytic performance of the catalyst samples was tested on the HDO reaction of guaiacol. Additionally, an HDO mechanism for Ni-doped WOxZrO2 catalyzed guaiacol conversion was proposed. High activity and selectivity rates were achieved during the experiments and cyclohexane was obtained as a main product in the presence of more than 10% of Ni-doped tungstated zirconia catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis, characterization, modeling and catalytic testing of tungstated zirconia supported Ni catalysts for Hydrodeoxygenation of Guaiacol
